meta.title: FLIP THE FUNNEL: How to Use Existing Customers to Gain New Ones
meta.author: Joseph Jaffe

parts.title: Foreword Summary
parts.body: In the Foreword of Joseph Jaffe's "Flip the Funnel," the author criticizes how companies handle customer service today, turning it into a cost-cutting "church of churn" instead of an opportunity to build customer loyalty. The societal shift towards transparency and authenticity makes old practices obsolete as consumers get honest feedback online, shifting power away from traditional marketing. Jaffe argues for turning customer experiences into the new focus of acquisition strategies, equating customer service with marketing and using real-world examples to highlight successful customer engagement strategies.

parts.title: Rethinking the Traditional Marketing Model
parts.body: In today's dynamic world, many traditional marketing concepts like S.T.P. (Segmenting, Targeting, Positioning) and the Four Ps (Product, Price, Place, Promotion) are becoming outdated. This text urges readers to rethink these conventional strategies and adopt a new model focused on Content, Commerce, Community, Context, Customization, and Conversation. The old marketing funnel - A.I.D.A (Awareness, Interest, Desire, Action) - is being challenged because it no longer reflects contemporary consumer behavior. Instead of being linear and predictable, customer journeys are now non-linear, filled with involvement, empowerment, and demonstration.

parts.title: Shifts in Business Strategy: From Expansion to Customer Centricity
parts.body: In recent times, the downfall of many companies stems from ignoring customer needs, focusing instead on expansion, and emphasizing diversification and acquisitions. When considering companies that have folded, many lacked customer referral programs or neglected to prioritize customer service and loyalty. A notable example is Starbucks, which lost sight of its core values by prioritizing breadth over depth, thereby alienating customers who perceived their offerings as too expensive. Marketing efforts such as defensive ad campaigns further illustrate companies losing their edge in the trust stakes. A shift in strategy is needed, from prioritizing acquisition to enhancing customer experience and loyalty.

parts.title: Enhancing Customer Engagement
parts.body: IBM makes it easy for customers to contact them through multiple channels like email, toll-free lines, live chat, and even virtual world meet-ups. This humanizes the technology space and enhances interactions. Conversely, Microsoft is criticized for its confusing support system, which often places the onus on customers to solve issues themselves. This highlights the importance of technology in improving relationships rather than just being seen as a cost-saving tool.

parts.title: Commitment and Customer Engagement
parts.body: The importance of commitment and follow-through in customer service is emphasized by a positive example involving Audi, where they ensured their customer was satisfied after a service visit. This kind of attention can lead to repeat business and word-of-mouth referrals.Even though reminders may seem unnecessary, they help customers keep track of appointments or key dates, acknowledging their busy lives and reinforcing their connection to the brand. Businesses are encouraged to engage customers without assuming constant top-of-mind awareness.

parts.title: Obama's Social Media Strategy
parts.body: Obama's campaign leveraged social media effectively, creating a vast online presence and utilizing platforms like MyBO to centralize activities. This approach allowed for ongoing dialogues through various content forms such as blogs, podcasts, and videos, establishing credibility with influential audiences. The intention was to create a movement driven by hope and change, encapsulated in the slogan "Yes We Can." This sentiment was a powerful incentive for participation, making the campaign feel more like a movement than an election, thereby engaging people on a deeper emotional level.

parts.title: Enhancing Customer Experience and Loyalty
parts.body: Companies should have a holistic approach to customer experience that blends existing service techniques and innovation to continuously add value. It is essential to prioritize customer loyalty and avoid creating hard-to-navigate loyalty programs that frustrate customers with conditions like blackouts. Businesses must avoid making it easy for competitors to outshine them through authentic, customer-friendly policies.

parts.title: Customer Service: A Strategic Driver and Differentiator
parts.body: Customer service is a strategic driver that needs to be at the forefront of business strategy. It should join the ranks of strategic planning, marketing and branding. It is vital for creating unique competitive advantages and can be a major differentiator from competitors. Organizations must shift from viewing customer service as a cost and instead treat it as a sound investment. This change requires overhauling recruitment, training, empowerment, and compensation of staff responsible for customer service, emphasizing the importance of not outsourcing these crucial functions and keeping them central to the company’s core.

parts.title: Navigating Virtual Worlds and Integrated Service
parts.body: Virtual Worlds Defined: The text expands on the definition of virtual worlds as environments where people interact through avatars or profiles, maintaining anonymity. Challenge: Companies face a dual challenge to deploy responsive capabilities in the "third dimension"—the blend of physical, digital, and virtual worlds—and interconnect these environments. Service Across Dimensions: Emphasis is placed on the need for integrated systems that document all customer interactions and enhance the consistency and quality of customer service across various platforms.

parts.title: Empowering Consumer-Driven Solutions and Community Interaction
parts.body: Method's Co-founders initiated user-driven content by partnering with Get Satisfaction, empowering their consumers to modify and curate brand-related questions. This crowdsourcing is akin to consumer-generated content meeting brand-oriented community interaction. It's about recognizing that no one knows the brand better than the customers themselves, emphasizing collaboration to unlock new potential while resonating with communities. An example highlights the potential of crowdsourced solutions: updating an iPhone and later finding apps missing led to a community-driven solution found through social media rather than official customer service; demonstrating how community can effectively provide solutions faster. Social media criticism noted it wasn't optimally enabling brands, hinting that the true strength of social media lies in retention rather than acquisition—consumers prefer genuine dialogues with other consumers over interactions with brands or products.

parts.title: The Shift in Consumer Trust and Influence
parts.body:
When shopping online, many rely on Google rankings, which do not differentiate between big corporations and individual blogs. For spontaneous buying decisions, people often turn to platforms like Twitter, trusting strangers' opinions due to a general faith in collective wisdom until they experience disappointment. Consequently, corporations no longer hold the power to control consumer purchasing behavior. The best hope for companies is to rely on their customers to advocate for their products' worth. Increasingly, without solicitation, customers are engaging in recommending goods to others, particularly through blogging platforms. These points highlight the need for companies to leverage consumer-generated content to maintain influence and foster customer pride in association with their brand.

Consumers trust peer recommendations more than marketing, which is crucial as bloggers and social media users voluntarily share experiences. Companies should strategize on engaging consumer advocates rather than rely only on traditional advertising. By fostering genuine relationships with customers, businesses can encourage them to participate in promoting the brand, thus enhancing organic growth through peer-to-peer endorsements. This organic involvement becomes more significant as more users engage in blogs and online discussions sharing personal insights about products, which companies can harness to influence future purchases positively. Meanwhile, brands must acknowledge the tangible and social currency value of referrals and align marketing strategies to emphasize authenticity and trustworthiness.

parts.title: Flipping the Corporate Funnel to Focus on Customer Experience
parts.body: Flipping the funnel involves embracing change within a company's culture, enhancing customer centric strategies by aligning retention and acquisition efforts. This change demands an organizational overhaul, focusing on customer experience rather than solely acquisition. Companies often get stuck between strategic and tactical phases in adopting customer-centric approaches, so a common entry point, usually strategic planning, is crucial for evolving and integrating corporate strategies effectively. In this context, questions arise about who should own the customer relationship - marketing, customer service, or an emerging entity such as a Chief Experience Officer. Different roles are suggested for different stages of organizational integration, from tactical customer services to a strategic CMO or holistic approaches. Building consensus and measuring success are pivotal in transitioning into a customer-experience-centric culture, driving home the importance of integrated roles and continuous support across all organization levels.

parts.title: Commitment to Change and Customer Centricity
parts.body: In a rapidly changing world, committed change within an organization is crucial for success. While some companies simply involve themselves in changes like a chicken in a breakfast, others like Virgin America or Zappos make a full commitment like a pig does. Committing to a new company culture or launching a new brand can translate into exceptional customer experiences, which lead to customer evangelism. It's not just about adding Wi-Fi on every flight like Virgin did, but about creating a genuinely engaged community of employees and customers that share common respect and purpose. Commitment to change requires being resource-intensive and embracing customer feedback to drive constant improvement. Virgin America exemplifies this by utilizing real-time feedback from customers to adjust their offerings, from diverse menus to customer service response. This approach requires a corporate maturity that embeds customer-centricity at the core of an organization’s DNA, allowing everyone in the company to own the customer experience.
